app.name: Rocks
app.info:
Sprout Labs - Learning Reimagined!

Ecosystems HD is a visually engaging and fun exploration of the major biomes of the Earth.

Ever wondered why plants and animals have specific adaptations. Why do plants in the rainforest have drip tip leaves? Why do conifers have needle leaves? Why does the jackrabbit have large ears? How has the camel adapted to the desert? What are some adaptations of marine organisms?

The Ecosystems HD app will be a treat for the curious learner.

Photos and videos describe the characteristics of the biomes and their inhabitants. The Did You Know section has "WOW" facts related to each biome. The text to speech function allows the text to be narrated.

The ecosystems matching game is a fun matching game for the various ecosystems and their inhabitants. The quiz is based on Bloom's taxonomy and is designed to test not only remembering and understanding but also applying, evaluating, and analyzing the concepts.

The content correlates to State Science Standards in the USA.

Features:

- Curated photos and videos with descriptive text with free periodic refresh of photos and videos.

- Did You Know section with WOW facts about each topic.

- Easy, Intermediate and Advanced level questions based on Bloom's Taxonomy to test knowledge about the various topics.

- Fun, matching game refreshed periodically with new content.


*****

 For more information on news and updates, like us on Facebook and follow us on Twitter @SproutLabs.

*****

For feature requests, feedback or support, send email to support@sproutlabs.net
app.curriculum:
Ecosystems App

Correlation to California State Science Standards

Grade K
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student will describe similarities and differences in the appearance and behavior of insects.
	2c – The student will identify major structures of common animals.

Grade 1
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows plants and animals inhabit different kinds of environments and have external features that help them thrive in different kinds of places.
	2b – The student knows that animals need food.
	2c – The student knows animals use plants for food.
	2d – The student knows how to infer what animals eat from the shape of their teeth.

Grade 2
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows organisms reproduce offspring of their own kind and that the offspring resemble the parents and each other.
	2b – The student knows the sequential stages of life cycle of animals.
	2c – The student knows many characteristics of organisms are inherited from parents.

Grade 3
*******
Life Sciences:
	2a – The student knows animals have structures that serve different functions in growth, survival, and reproduction.
	2d – The student knows when the environment changes, some animals survive while others die or move to new locations.

_______

introTexts.item: Rocks, Every living thing, plant or animal, has a home. It's natural home is called its habitat.
Rocks, These living things or biotic components, live in balance and interact with each other and with the non-living or abiotic components.
Rocks, Abiotic components include light, air, water, soil and temperature. Together with the biotic components, they make up an ecosystem.
Rocks, A biome is a large region that has plants, animals, and other living things that have adapted to the environmental conditions.
Rocks, A biome can have many different ecosystems.
Rocks, Plants and animals survive in their environment because of how they behave and how they are created. This is called adaptation.
Rocks, When the environment changes too quickly for living things to adapt, they can die, and entire species may become extinct.
Rocks, Thus, protecting the earth’s biomes, ecosystems, and habitats is very important!
Rocks, Go ahead and start exploring the major biomes and ecosystems of the world!

mainText.mainText:
Do you have a rock collection? If so, you already know how fascinating rocks can be! This lesson explains how rocks are formed, how they change, and how we use them. 
 What is a rock? Rocks are naturally occurring solid combinations of minerals and sometimes other materials too. The common rock granite is made of the minerals quartz, feldspar and biotite. When only one mineral is present, the object is a mineral, not rock. 
 Scientists classify rocks into three categories: igneous, sedimentary, and metamorphic. These are all part of the rock cycle. 
 Igneous rocks begin deep in the Earth, which contains solid and molten materials such as silicon, magnesium and iron. Magma bursts through the Earth's surface via volcanoes and cracks in the Earth's crust. At the surface it's called lava. Lava hardens to become new crust. 
 Rocks are exposed to ocean waves and weather. They slowly break down into pebbles and sand. Sedimentary rocks are made of the resulting sand and mud, material from plants and animals, and minerals left over when liquid evaporates. These all compact and harden to become rock. 
 Metamorphic rocks are made when rocks experience new temperature and pressure conditions. For example, contact with magma could cause rock to liquefy and then recrystallize into a different type of rock. 
 Scientists believe that humans have been using rocks for about 3.5 million years. Stone arrowheads were among our first tools. Today we mine rocks for use in roads, statues, buildings, chalkboards, jewelry, cosmetics and many other items.

item.name: Grassland-P5.png
item.title: Fertile grasslands are used for agriculture

item.name: Grassland-P6.png
item.title: New Zealand farm on a grassland

item.name: Grassland-P8.png
item.title: Camouflaged giraffe in the African Bush

item.text: Petrology is the study of the origin and composition of rocks.
Geology is the study of the Earth, rocks and the rock cycle.
A grain of sand is like a tiny rock! Look at one under a microscope.
Some rocks contain mineralites in addition to minerals. Glass is a mineralite.
Glass is made from superheated sand.
Igneous means fire in Latin. Igneous rocks come from magma.
When molten material cools inside the Earth's crust, intrusive rock is formed.
When lava cools outside the Earth's crust, extrusive rock is formed.
The Earth's outer rocky layer is called the lithosphere. It includes oceanic crust and continental crust.
Basalt is the most common rock on Earth. Much of the ocean's crust is basalt.
The Earth's continental crust is mainly andesite rock.
Marble is a metamorphic rock. It is usually made from limestone.
At least 300 degrees Fahrenheit (150 Celsius) are needed to cause metamorphic changes.
The Taj Mahal is made entirely of marble.
Geodes are ordinary-looking igneous or sedimentary rocks on the outside but contain beautiful crystals on the inside.
Meteorites, or rocks from outer space, help scientists learn about our solar system
One of the oldest rocks on Earth was brought from the Moon. Scientists believe it's about 4.5 billion years old.
The Himalayas are among the world’s youngest mountains. Scientists estimate that they formed 30 million years ago.
To estimate the age of a sedimentary rock, scientists consider its thickness, its mineral layers, and the plant and animal remains it may contain.
Mountains form when enormous pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up.

item.title: The Life cycle of a Butterfly
Butterfly laying eggs in a garden
Mountains
item.description: Mountains are not eternal. They form when pieces of the Earth's crust collide and bunch up. Mountains will erode away.

item.title: Mineral combinations
item.description: Rocks are solid combinations of minerals and sometimes other materials too. Although they might seem permanent, they change in a cycle.

item.title: Igneous rocks
item.description: Igneous rocks begin deep in the Earth as solid and molten materials.

item.title: Lava
item.description: Lava hardens to become new crust and rocks.

item.title: Amethyst
item.description: This amethyst geode is a spectacular example of an igneous rock.

item.title: Extrusive rock
item.description: When lava cools outside of the Earth's crust, it forms extrusive rock.

item.title: Magma plumes
item.description: The North Mariana Island and other islands are formed by magma plumes.

item.title: Sedimentary rocks
item.description: Sedimentary rocks are made when material is weathered.

item.title: Rock erosion
item.description: Rocks are weathered by ocean waves and break down into pebbles and sand.

item.title: Sand grains
item.description: A grain of sand is like a tiny rock! Look at one.

item.title: Glass
item.description: Did you know? Glass is made from superheated sand.

item.title: Sedimentary rocks
item.description: Sedimentary rocks are made of sand and mud, organic material, and minerals left when liquid evaporates.

item.title: Metamorphic rocks
item.description: Metamorphic rocks are made when rocks experience new temperature and pressure conditions.

item.title: Magma
item.description: Magma can create metamorphic rock by causing a rock to melt and reform.

item.title: meteorite
item.description: A meteorite is a rare type of metamorphic rock. This Odessa meteorite fragment hit Earth approximately 64,000 years ago.

item.title: stones
item.description: Humans have used stone since before recorded history. These arrowheads are an example of our earliest use of stone.

item.title: Taj Mahal
item.description: The Taj Mahal is made entirely of marble, a type of metamorphic rock.

item.title: marble
item.description: Marble rock was carved into this statue of Queen Victoria.

item.title: skyscrapers
item.description: Skyscrapers are constructed of granite, marble and other types of rock.

item.question: For an object to be a rock in geologists' terms, what must it contain?
Creating sedimentary rocks primarily involves _________________.
Which rock type is most directly associated with molten (melted) material?
Which rocks are especially common in riverbeds?
Creating metamorphic rocks primarily involves _________________.

choice.answer: The compaction of sand and organic material

item.question: Judging from its name, sandstone is most likely ________.
Which event would most likely help create metamorphic rocks?
The Earth's crust __________.
Which rock would be most likely to contain glass?
Which of the following is true?
Which statement is true?

choice.answer: Oceanic crust is older than continental crust
Sedimentary rocks are not placed under pressure

item.question: To make a mountain, what must occur?
Oceanic crust is typically made through ________.
How would intrusive rock most likely reach the Earth's surface?

choice.answer: By filling cracks in the sea floor

item.question: If a planet did not have much weather, which rock type would take extra-long to form?

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Various stages of the rock cycle

hotspot.title: Sedimentation
hotspot.text: Sedimentation is the deposition of sediments (natural material that is broken down by erosion and weathering) that results in the formation of sedimentary rock.\n

hotspot.title: Sedimentary rocks
hotspot.text:
Sedimentary rocks are formed when layers of sediments: minerals and particles accumulate on top of each other and are transformed by pressure into rock. 
Once the sediments have been formed by weathering and erosion, they are transported and deposited by wind (Aeolian or eolian process) water (fluvial process), glaciers, and ice. 
Sedimentary rocks are economically valuable compared to other rocks since they are a source of many fossil fuels and ores.

hotspot.title: Metamorphism
hotspot.text: When physical or chemical changes result in a transformation and rearrangement of atoms in a rock into a new crystal structure, the process is known as Metamorphism. Pressure, heat, and fluids can cause metamorphism.\n

hotspot.title: Metamorphic rocks
hotspot.text: Extreme heat and pressure can cause significant physical and/or chemical changes in a rock. The process of metamorphism transforms existing igneous, older metamorphic or sedimentary rocks into metamorphic rocks. The original rock is known as the protolith. \n

hotspot.title: Melting
hotspot.text: The process through which a substance undergoes a phase transition from a solid to a liquid is known as melting.\n

hotspot.title: Magma
hotspot.text: Magma is a mixture of molten rock, solids, crystals, gases, and other chemicals that is found beneath the surface of the Earth.\n

hotspot.title: Crystallization
hotspot.text: The process of forming solid crystals (ordered arrangement of atoms in a material) from a solution is known as crystallization.\n

hotspot.title: Igneous rocks
hotspot.text: Igneous rocks are formed when lava or magma cool and solidify. Igneous rocks that form from magma are known as intrusive or plutonic rocks while those formed from lava are known as extrusive or volcanic rocks.\n

hotspot.title: Erosion
hotspot.text: Erosion is the natural process by which wind, water, glaciers, and ice remove soil and rock from the Earth's surface and move and deposit them in a different location.\n

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Lava flow reaching an ocean and forming igneous rock

hotspot.title: Lava
hotspot.text: Lava is molten rock that comes out of a volcano. After it cools and solidifies it forms igneous rock. Lava can be at very high temperatures ranging from 750C-1300C. \nIn this picture, lava flow reaching the ocean is being cooled by the water to form a lava delta. Lava deltas can collapse without warning since they are very unstable. The steam produced when the lava and water react is very hot and can contain particles of volcanic rock.\n

hotspot.title: Igneous rock formation
hotspot.text: Igneous rocks are formed when lava or magma cool and solidify. Igneous rocks that form from magma are also known as intrusive or plutonic rocks while those formed from lava are known as extrusive or volcanic rocks. \nThere are three types of igneous rocks based on their composition: felsic or silicic that is high in silica and aluminum, intermediate or andesitic that is lower in silica and aluminum, and mafic or basaltic that is high in iron and magnesium.\n

hotspot.title: Oceanic crust
hotspot.text: Oceanic crust is formed when liquid lava cools quickly under the oceans. This is the outermost layer of the Earth's lithosphere.\n

hotspot.title: Continental crust
hotspot.text: Continental crust is the layer of the earth that comprises the continental shelves and the igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks that are a part of the continents.\n

hotspot.title: Lithosphere
hotspot.text: Earth's lithosphere comprises the oceanic and continental crust and the outermost solid layer of the mantle. It is made of tectonic plates.\n

hotspot.title: Asthenosphere
hotspot.text: Asthenosphere is the upper layer of the mantle and is located below the lithosphere. It comprises rocks that can be deformed. The Asthenosphere is typically associated with plate tectonics (large scale movement of the Earth's lithosphere).\n

hotspot.title: Mantle
hotspot.text: 84% of the Earth's volume is in the mantle, which is a rocky shell. The upper mantle starts at the base of the crust and extends to about 250 miles. It is made of magnesium and iron silicates such as olivine and pyroxene. The upper mantle is rigid on the top and is made of liquid rock below.\n

hotspot.title: Lower Mantle
hotspot.text: The lower mantle contains silicon, magnesium and oxygen and has 50% of the mass of the planet. It is hotter and denser than the upper mantle.\n

hotspot.title: Inner core
hotspot.text: The inner core is 780 miles thick and is very hot (10,000F). Despite the extremely high temperature, the inner core is solid due to very high pressures. \n

hotspot.title: Outer core
hotspot.text: The outer core is made of iron, nickel, sulfur, and oxygen. It is cooler than the inner core (7200-9000F) and is liquid.\n

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Formation of various igneous rock structures

hotspot.title: Magmachamber, batholith
hotspot.text: This region shows a magmachamber or batholith, which means deep rock. When magma cools deep inside the Earth's crust and transforms into intrusive igneous or plutonic rock in a particular location it forms a batholith. \nTypically, batholiths are made of granite or quartz. Sometimes multiple plutons or individual rocks can converge to form a large expanse of granite rock as observed in the Sierra Nevada Batholith that make up a vast portion of the Sierra Nevada mountains in California.\n

hotspot.title: Dike
hotspot.text: This region shows the formation of a geologic dike. When there are cracks in existing rock, magma can force its way through. As the magma cools and solifies, it forms sheets of igneous rock that cut across the existing rocks.\n

hotspot.title: Laccolith
hotspot.text: This region shows the formation of a laccolith. A laccolith is a sheet like formation of intrusive igneous rock between two layers of sedimentary rock. Since the magma from which the igneous rocks form has high pressure, it can force an upward movement of the existing sedimentary rock thus forming a dome or mushroom shape with a flat base.\n

hotspot.title: Pegmatite
hotspot.text: A pegmatite is composed of crystalline, intrusive igneous rock that forms in the final stages of the magmachamber cooling and crystallization. As the magma cools to form rock, water is pushed out into molten rock and this water keeps getting concentrated with many different elements. In the final stages of cooling and crystallization, the water rich magma transforms into pegmatite containing large crystals of many rare minerals.\n

hotspot.title: Sill
hotspot.text: This region shows a sill, which is a horizontal sheet of igneous rock between older layers of sedimentary or metamorphic rock. Unlike dikes in which the magma intrudes relatively vertical, sills are formed by relatively horizontal intrusion of magma.\n

hotspot.title: Stratovolcano
hotspot.text: This region shows the processes associated with the formaiton of a stratovolcano also known as a composite volcano. A stratovolcano is typically a tall, conical volcano and is characterized by periods of explosive and quiet eruptions. Some stratovolcanoes can have collapsed craters and are called calderas. The Yellowstone caldera is part of the Yellowstone Stratovolcano.\n

hotspot.title: Cape Spencer
hotspot.text: This is a picture taken at Cape Spencer at the entrance to the Cross Sound near Juneau in the Glacier Bay National Park in Alaska. This is the northernmost entrance to Alaska's Inland Passage.\n

hotspot.title: Jointed rocks
hotspot.text: Igneous or metamorphic rocks seen at Cape Spencer, Alaska show increased erosion along the joined areas.

hotspot.title: Travertine
hotspot.text: Travertine is a type of natural stone like marble, slate, granite, limestone etc. It has different color and hardness compared to other natural stones and is typically formed in hot mineral springs and limetone caves. It is a type of sedimentary rock formed by precipitation of carbonate minerals.\n

hotspot.title: Yellowstone
hotspot.text: Yellowstone National Park was establoished in 1872 as the first National Park in the US. It is located mostly in Wyoming, but does extend into Montana and Idaho. Yellowstone derives its name from the Yellowstone River, which in turn gets its name from the yellow colored rocky cliffs on its banks. \nFamous for its wildlife, geothermal features, and geology, Yellowstone is also part of the largest volcanic system in North America. The Yellowstone Caldera has been termed a stratovolcano because the caldera was formed by large explosive eruptions.\n

hotspot.title: Grand Canyon
hotspot.text:
The Grand Canyon area showcases one of the most complete sequences of rock on Earth. Nearly 40 major sedimentary rock layers are exposed in the Grand Canyon National Park area and range in age from about 200 million to nearly 2 billion years old. Most of these rocks were deposited in warm, shallow seas and near ancient sea shores in western North America. Both marine and terrestrial sediments are represented, including fossilized sand dunes from an extinct desert.
The first sedimentary layer of rock, the Bass Formation was laid down 1.25 billion years ago. Fossils of Stromatolites or coastal algae are seen preserved in these rocks. Volcanic activity formed the Cardenas Basalt between 1.25 billion and 1.1 billion years ago. Coastal and shallow seas formed the Chuar group of rocks between 825 million and 1.1 billion years ago.
 Subsequent rock formations indicate a sequence of retreating oceans alternating with a coastal environment.

hotspot.title: Sedimentary rocks in Grand Canyon
hotspot.text: The Kaibab limestone forms the topmost layer of rock and is the youngest rock found at the Grand Canyon National Park. This layer was formed when the Grand Canyon was a part of a warm, shallow sea with a sandy floor. Below the Kaibab, the Toroweap layer is made of the same material as the Kaibab but has a different color and was formed at a different time. The Coconino sandstones below the Toroweap layer are made of quartz and were formed from petrified sand dunes during a time when the the area was composed entirely of sand resulting in a desert like environment. The red colored cliffs of the Hermit Shale are rich in iron (hence the red color) and were formed when this region was part of a logoon like environment with swamps. This layer of rock has a lot of plant fossils.\n

hotspot.title: Granite
hotspot.text: Granite is a light colored, intrusive, igneous rock consisting of silicate based minerals like quartz, mica and feldspar. It is the most abundant rock in the continental crust. Granite rocks can get uplifted and exposed on the surface of the earth when the sedimentary rocks covering them are eroded. Granite is used in a variety of applications since it resists abrasion and weathering, it can be polished, and it can bear a lot of weight.\n

hotspot.title: Quarry
hotspot.text: Rocks and minerals are extracted from a quarry, which is a type of open-pit mine. Open pit mines are used to extract rocks and minerals that are found near the surface. Sand, gravel, building materials, and stones such as marble, sandstone, granite, limestone etc are quarried. The quarry stones, which are used for construction purposes, are cut into slabs before they are transported out of the quarry.\n

topic.name: minerals
topic.mainText:
What is a mineral? Minerals such as gold, calcium and sodium are the building blocks of rocks. They are inorganic. That is, although rocks may contain matter from plants and animals, minerals do not. Minerals are purely chemical. They are typically solid at room temperature. 
 Minerals are made of the elements listed on the Periodic Table. Minerals may consist of just one element, such as gold, or they can be combinations of elements. Quartz, for example, is made of silicon and oxygen. 
 Plants and animals must adapt to be able to survive the desert’s tough conditions. Desert plants like cactus have thick and fleshy stems to store water. They also have spiny leaves to prevent loss of water through transpiration, which is similar to sweating. 
 Scientists classify minerals in several ways. Some categories are color, luster, hardness, specific gravity, and cleavage or how the mineral breaks. 
 When you're identifying minerals, color is helpful but not enough. Many minerals are found in multiple colors. Also, minerals may be impure; extra chemicals can change their color. Diamonds are made in every color of the rainbow. 
 “Luster” describes how a mineral reflects light. Some terms used to describe luster are brilliant, metallic, silky and dull. 
 Hardness is another way to classify a mineral. Hardness is measured by scratching a mineral. Diamonds are the hardest mineral on earth; they can scratch anything. 
 Specific gravity refers to density. Two mineral chunks of the same size can have different weights. Specific gravity can be measured by comparing a mineral's weight to an equal volume of water. 
 Cleavage and other characteristics of breakage help people classify minerals. For example, some crystals break with jagged edges. Others break along smooth planes. 
 People identify minerals in many other ways such as acid tests, radioactivity tests, and simply using their taste buds.

item.name: Desert-P7.png
item.title: Sahara desert sand dunes
item.attribution: Picture taken by Raul Santos de la Camara

item.text: Because elements can be combined in countless ways, scientists haven't set a limit for how many minerals exist.
The International Mineralogical Association recognizes approximately 4700 mineral species.
The most common mineral on Earth is quartz.
Amethyst, citrine and other types of quartz are the most common minerals used in jewelry.
The elements oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.
Mercury and water ice are exceptions to the rule that minerals are solid at room temperature.
The Mohs Hardness Scale is used to describe a mineral's hardness.
Because diamonds are so hard, they are useful in drill bits and other tools that cut.
Talc is the softest rock. It is used in body powder.
Crystals are minerals that have their atoms arranged in three-dimensional patterns.
Crystals are most likely to form when magma cools slowly and under great pressure.
When lava cools quickly, it's likely to form glassy rocks, not crystals.
Most of the Earth's crust is made of silicate minerals, which contain silicon and oxygen.
Eight important mineral groups are the silicates, native elements, sulfides, oxides, halides, carbonates, sulfates, and phosphates.
Native elements appear in nature uncombined with others. Examples are gold, silver and copper.
Halides are part halogen. Chloride and many other halides are salts.
Phosphates, which include the element phosphorus, are valued primarily as fertilizer and for detergents.
Heavy metal waste from phosphate mining has contaminated drinking water.
Sulfides, which combine sulfur with other minerals, may smell like rotten eggs. They are especially useful in medicine, art and agriculture.
Diamonds and pencil “lead” are made from the same element: carbon. The different look is explained by diamond's crystalline structure.

item.title: Newly hatched caterpillar eating its egg shells
Monarch caterpillar to Chrysalis time lapse
Minerals
item.description: Minerals such as gold are the building blocks of rocks. A picture of the Round Mountain Gold Mine in Nevada.

item.title: mineral composition
item.description: Oxygen, silicon, aluminum, iron, magnesium, calcium, potassium, and sodium make up 98% of all minerals on Earth.

item.title: Atacama
item.description: Aluminum, the third most abundant mineral, makes up about 8% of the Earth's weight.

item.title: Gobi Desert
item.description: Calcium, seen in the white rock here, is abundant too. It comprises pearls, eggshells, antacid tablets and your bones.

item.title: Palm tree
item.description: Sodium silicate, meanwhile, makes up much of the Earth's crust.

item.title: Cacti
item.description: Minerals like these are all inorganic. That is, minerals do not contain plant or animal materials.

item.title: Cactus leaf
item.description: For example, quartz is made entirely of silicon and oxygen.

item.title: Desert plants
item.description: Quartz is the most common mineral on Earth.

item.title: Mulga
item.description: Amethyst, a type of quartz, is popular for jewelry. But how can we tell all the stones apart?

item.title: Acacia
item.description: We classify minerals by sight but that's not enough. Diamonds, for instance, occur in many colors.

item.title: Camel
item.description: Minerals are also categorized by luster. Luster describes how a mineral reflects light.

item.title: Camel eyes
item.description: The Moh's Hardness Test involves scratching a mineral to identify it.

item.title: Camel legs
item.description: Diamond is the hardest mineral.

item.title: Jackrabbit
item.description: Talc is the softest mineral. It is used in body powder.

item.title: Jackrabbit
item.description: Mineral cleavage refers to how a mineral breaks. It is another clue for mineral classification.

item.title: Desert Tortoise
item.description: Fluorescent and radioactive tests also help scientists identify minerals.

item.title: Thorny Devil Lizard
item.description: Minerals take many forms. Mercury is one of the few minerals that is liquid at room temperature.

item.title: San people
item.description: Diamonds and pencil graphite are both made of carbon. Diamonds are carbon crystals. Graphite is carbon sheets.

item.title: San people
item.description: Citrine, diamonds and other crystals are most likely to form when magma cools slowly.

item.title: San people
item.description: Minerals should be used responsibly. One risk is phosphates. These are used in fertilizers and detergents but contaminate drinking water.

item.question: How are minerals related to rocks?

choice.answer: In geology, minerals and rocks are synonyms.
Rocks are the building blocks of minerals.

item.question: What is luster?
The way a mineral divides is called ________.
Which mineral is the most abundant on Earth?
Which is a native mineral?
What causes a diamond to be colorful?
Why does a diamond's carbon look different from a pencil's carbon?

choice.answer: Pencil carbon has been exposed to higher temperatures
Pencil carbon is mixed with phosphates

item.question: What effect do high heat and pressure have upon minerals?

choice.answer: They increase the likelihood of contamination

item.question: Why are diamonds considered more valuable than glass?
Which sense can help us identify minerals?
What is an important difference between minerals and rocks?

choice.answer: Minerals do not contain organic material
Rocks do not contain organic material
Minerals are not recycled by the Earth

item.question: Which characteristic helps make mercury a mineral?

choice.answer: It is solid at room temperature

item.question: If a unknown item is a gas, it is most likely ___________.
If a planet did not have any oxygen, it would also lack _______.
What is the most reliable way to tell whether a gemstone is real or imitation diamond?

hotspot.title: Lazurite
hotspot.text: Lazurite derives its name from Lazhward meaning blue in Persian. It is also known as ultramarine and is a component of Lapis Lazuli, which is a rock made of lazurite, calcite and pyrite. It is formed in metamorphosed limestone.\n

hotspot.title: Tigers Eye
hotspot.text: Tiger's eye is a metamorphic rock that is golden or red brown in color. It is a type of quartz and exhibits a cat's eye effect because of parallel growth of quartz crystals between limonite. \n

hotspot.title: Moss agate
hotspot.text: Moss agate is formed from volcanic rocks. It is a semi-precious gemstone also known as mocha stone. Primarily made of silicon dioxide, the green filament patterns resemble moss growing on a stone and hence the name.\n

hotspot.title: Sodalite
hotspot.text: A royal blue ornamental gemstone, sodalite, has high sodium content and hence the name. Although similar to lazurite and lapis lazuli, it does not contain pyrite. It is found in plutonic igenous rocks.\n

hotspot.title: Open pit mine
hotspot.text: Open pit mines are used to extract rocks and minerals that are found near the surface. The mines start small and then keep getting larger until the mineral resource has been completely extracted or it becomes difficult to mine. What happens to the land after the mine has been exhausted?\n

hotspot.title: Udachnaya diamond mine
hotspot.text: Udachnaya pipe meaning lucky pipe in Russian, is an open pit diamond mine and is part of the Mir pipe. The volcanic rock kimberlite is typically associated with diamond deposits as well as garnets and spinels. Kimberlite pipes are formed as a result of eruption of deep volcanoes and have the shape of a carrot that rises from a dike. \n

hotspot.title: Kalgoorlie gold mine
hotspot.text: The Super Pit or the Fimiston Open Pit is Australia's largest open cut gold mine. Over 80% of the gold in this mine is found in host rocks that are part of what is known as the Golden Mile Dolerite or the richest mile on Earth. Every year over 85 million tons of materials is moved from the pit of which 12 million tons is material that has gold.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Kalgoorlie Super pit
hotspot.text:
Fluids containing gold and minerals are formed deep inside the Earth's crust and are forced up into fractures in the rock during tectonic activity, where the gold eventually crystallizes.
The gold formed in Kalgoorlie during a period of intense intrusion of igneous rock and metamorphism.
Gold has been discovered on every continent but is very rare. 80% of the world's gold is still in the ground.

hotspot.title: Fikkila mine
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Desert
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Desert
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Desert
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Desert
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

hotspot.title: Australia, Desert
hotspot.text: Rocks are formed by weathering by wind and water.\n

topic.name: soil
topic.mainText:
Soil is like a nutrition bar for plants. It holds all the nutrients that plants need to survive. Soil has developed over hundreds of millions of years. It's created as weather erodes rocks and when plants and animals leave material behind. Minerals mix with organic material and water to become soil. 
 Much of soil is alive! Bacteria, algae and fungi in soil break material into useful nutrients. They make it possible for larger life forms to survive. 
 The Earth's soil is organized into several layers called horizons. The topmost layer contains humus, which is leaf litter and decomposed organic matter. The next layer is topsoil. This is where seeds germinate and roots grow. It has sediment from rocks and contains some humus too. 
 The next layer down is called the eluviation layer. It is light colored, made mostly of sand and silt. Most minerals and clay drip down to the subsoil below. Subsoil is rich with clay and minerals from water, such as iron and calcium carbonate. 
 The bottommost layers are rocky. First there is regolith. Regolith is a mix of broken bedrock and dark soil, which is composed of dead organic matter. A solid layer of bedrock lays beneath it all. 
 Erosion is the carrying away of rocks and soil. Erosion is caused by wind, precipitation and gravity. Although erosion is a natural process, it's problematic when we lose soil for crops, forests and other habitats. Trees can help fight erosion because their roots stabilize the soil.

item.name: Forests-P4.png
item.title: Deciduous trees lose leaves in the Fall

item.name: Forests-P5.png
item.title: Lichens and moss share a habitat

item.name: Forests-P7.png
item.title: Colorful macaws are found in the tropical rain forests

item.text: Soil formation is called pedogenesis.
Soil is heavily influenced by its environment. Important factors include climate, relief (slope), local organisms, local minerals and time.
Most of the Earth's soil is younger than 2.5 million years old.
Soil is classified by size. Clay soil is made of especially small particles. That's why it can filter to the bottom of the soil horizons.
Silt particles are slightly larger than clay particles.
Common minerals in soil are quartz, feldspar, calcite and mica.
From a gardening perspective, “good soil” contains about 45% minerals (sand, silt and clay), 25% water, and 5% organic material. The rest is air!
Water is important to the effectiveness of soil. The pH or acidity of soil affects the availability of nutrients to plants.
Liquid water and glaciers can carry soil thousands of miles.
Wind can move sand and silt hundreds of miles.
When land is steep, soil is less able to hold minerals; they run off.
Fall colors are due to plants withdrawing chlorophyll from their leaves during shortening days of fall
Soil may contain more than a million species of microbes per gram!
It takes about 800 to 1000 years for nature to create an inch of soil.
Nowadays, because of certain farming practices, one inch of topsoil is lost about every 28 years.
Soil stores about 10% of the world's carbon dioxide emissions.
Creatures living in the soil are classified as macrofauna, mesofauna and microfauna.
Examples of macrofauna are worms, beetles and termites.
Mesofauna include mites and nematodes.
The tiniest creatures in the soil are protozoa and other microfauna.

item.title: Monarch caterpillar turning into a cocoon
Tropical rainforest
item.description: Countless varieties of soil can be found around the Earth.

item.title: Emergent layer
item.description: Scientists study soil to make better decisions for solving hunger and urban growth.

item.title: Temperate forest

item.title: Fall colors
item.description: Topsoil is where seeds germinate and roots grow. It has sediment from rocks and contains some humus too.

item.title: Deciduous in winter

item.title: Bird migration

item.title: Taiga plants

item.title: Grizzly bear
item.description: Soil regulates our environment by absorbing carbon dioxide. Protecting soil can help prevent global warming.

item.question: What is soil made of?
What is humus?
Where is most clay located?
Which of these forces causes soil erosion?
What are the major layers of soil called?
Why is soil essential to life?

choice.answer: Plants do not grow in sandy areas.
Soil is the source of all bacteria.

item.question: Why does soil take so long to form?

choice.answer: Rock erosion is a slow process.
Most minerals seep into the Earth.

item.question: According to the narrator, how is soil “alive?”

choice.answer: It moves with the help of natural forces.
It contains very small life forms.
It is part of the rock cycle.

item.question: Why don't we see all the minerals in soil?

choice.answer: Minerals comprise a tiny percentage of good soil.
The minerals are present as small particles.
Minerals are only present in subsoil.

item.question: How does soil become layered?

choice.answer: Materials fall according to size and weight.

item.question: What is a possible consequence of erosion?

choice.answer: Algae and fungi will be washed away.

item.question: How does the eluviation layer compare to regolith?

choice.answer: The eluviation layer is lighter in color.
The eluviation layer is darker in color.

item.question: How would relief or slope most likely influence a region's topsoil?

choice.answer: A steep region would have more topsoil.
A steep region would have less topsoil.
A steep region would have richer topsoil.
A steep region would have darker topsoil.

item.question: How would deforestation influence an area's soil?

choice.answer: Soil erosion would become less likely.
Soil erosion would become more likely.

item.question: How is subsoil different from topsoil?

hotspot.title: Peaty soil
hotspot.text: When organic matter decays and accumulates, it forms peaty soil. Due to how its formed, peaty soil contains more organic matter than most of the soils but has less nutrients. It is generally found in marshy areas.\n

hotspot.title: Clay soil
hotspot.text: Clay soil has poor drainage and is prone to water logging. Since it is formed from the sedimentary deposits from the erosion of rock, it has fine grained material, less air space, and occurs naturally. A lot of fertilizers need to be added to make clay soil cultivable. \n

hotspot.title: Sandy soil
hotspot.text: Sandy soil has small rock and mineral particles and is formed from the disintegration of limestone, granite, quartz and other types of rocks. If sandy soil has lots of organic material then it can be used for culitvation. Since it does not retain moisture that can cause root decay, sandy soil is good for plants\n

hotspot.title: Chalky soil
hotspot.text: Chalky soil is alkaline in nature and is prone to dryness. It requires more watering and fertlizing than any other type of soil. Since it also blocks nutrients for the plants, it is often not considered a good soil for plantation.\n

hotspot.title: Loamy soil
hotspot.text: Considered the perfect soil and ideal for culitvation, loamy soil consists of sand, silt and clay. Due to its texture it can both retain water easily and allow good drainage.\n

hotspot.title: Silty soil
hotspot.text: Silty soil is composed of organic materials and minerals like quartz and has more nutrients than sandy soil. It is thus considered to be the most fertile soil and is ideal for cultivation since it offers good drainage as well.\n

hotspot.title: Humus
hotspot.text: The top, organic layer of soil, made up mostly of leaf litter and humus (decomposed organic matter).\n

hotspot.title: A Horizon
hotspot.text: A Horizon is the layer called topsoil. It is found below the O horizon and above the E horizon. Seeds germinate and plant roots grow in this dark-colored layer. It is made up of humus (decomposed organic matter) mixed with mineral particles.\n

hotspot.title: E Horizon
hotspot.text: E Horizon - This eluviation (leaching) layer is light in color; this layer is beneath the A Horizon and above the B Horizon. It is made up mostly of sand and silt, having lost most of its minerals and clay as water drips through the soil (in the process of eluviation).\n

hotspot.title: B Horizon
hotspot.text: B Horizon is also called the subsoil. This layer is beneath the E Horizon and above the C Horizon. It contains clay and mineral deposits (like iron, aluminum oxides, and calcium carbonate) that it receives from layers above it when mineralized water drips from the soil above.\n

hotspot.title: Termite mound
hotspot.text: Termites play a very important role in nutrient cycling of dead plant material by breaking down cellulose and help in soil formation and movement and transportation of soil material.\n

hotspot.title: Termite ecosystem
hotspot.text: Like earthworms on farmland, termites aerate the surrounding soil, allowing more water to penetrate. This activity, along with termite droppings, creates highly fertile patches of earth with a higher percentage of nitrogen and phosphorous than ground farther away. The termite mounds thus have been shown to sustain significantly more shrubs, fruit-bearing trees, bugs, and animals in the African savanna. \n

hotspot.title: Tufa
hotspot.text: The limestone towers are made mostly of calcite deposited in the salty and alkaline water of Mono Lake, in California. These rocks formed under water when calcium-rich spring water at the bottom of the lake bubbled up into the alkaline lake, forming these calcite "tufa" towers. If the lake level drops, the tufa towers appear in interesting formations.\n

hotspot.title: Mono lake
hotspot.text: Mono Lake lies in the landlocked Mono Basin where any dissolved salts in the runoff remain in the lake and raise the water's pH levels and salt concentration. The basin was created by geological forces over the last five million years: basin and range crustal stretching and associated volcanism and faulting at the base of the Sierra Nevada.\n

hotspot.title: Delicate arch
hotspot.text: The widely recognized Delicate Arch is a natural arch 65ft tall. It is located in the Arches National Park near Moab, Utah. Composed of Entrada Sandstone from the Jurassic period, the arch was formed by a combination of weathering and erosion.\n

hotspot.title: Arches National Park
hotspot.text: Formed over an underground salt bed known as the Paradox formation, layers of sediments were deposited onto this salt bed over millions of years and were converted into rock. As the salt bed buckled due to the weight of the sandstones, it led to the formation of domes and cavities. Subsequently, weathering and erosion of these rocks due to water, ice, and wind lead to the formation of some of the magnificent structures seen at the Arches National Park.\n

hotspot.title: Delicate arch
hotspot.text: The widely recognized Delicate Arch is a natural arch 65ft tall. It is located in the Arches National Park near Moab, Utah. Composed of Entrada Sandstone from the Jurassic period, the arch was formed by a combination of weathering and erosion.\n

hotspot.title: Courthouse towers
hotspot.text: The Courthouse towers are tall columns of stone rising to 4800ft that were a part of the Entrada Sandstone. Weathering by wind and water formed the arches and spires.\n

hotspot.title: Balanced rock
hotspot.text: Balanced rock is one of the famous landmarks of the Arches National Park. The top rock is the size of three school buses.\n

hotspot.title: Plants prevent erosion
hotspot.text: Plants help prevent erosion by providing a vegetative cover, decreasing runoff, and protecting the soil from wind resulting in lower wind erosion. Further, the roots hold the soil together reducing water and wind erosion.\n

hotspot.title: Erosion by water
hotspot.text: Evidence of erosion by water and wind.\n

hotspot.title: Glaciers
hotspot.text: Glaciers are frozen rivers of ice and sediments that flow downhill. As snow falls it compresses the layers below to form ice. If the ice is formed on a slope, then this massive sheet of ice and snow begins to slowly move downhill. Most glaciers are found near the poles but they also exits on all the continents.\n

hotspot.title: Glacial erosion
hotspot.text: When glaciers flow over rocks, the ice and sediments in the glacier can act as sandpaper and pulverize the rock below. This process is known as abrasion. This can lead to the formation of deep valleys and mountain slopes. \nGlaciers can also soften and remove blocks of rock. This happens because the water in the glacier can penetrate cracks in the rock. As the water freezes, it expands leading to a fracture in the rock.\n

mainText.mainText:
Fossils are remains and signs of ancient living things. They are the only evidence we have that certain species existed. Fossils reveal a history of the Earth's earliest bacteria, flowers, fish and other life. 
 Not everything that dies becomes a fossil; most plants and animals are soon recycled by nature. But sometimes life is preserved in its entirety as a whole fossil. For a whole fossil to occur, a creature must be buried away from all oxygen. This might happen with help from a mudflow, glacier or tree sap. 
 Compared with whole fossils, cast fossils are more common. Bones, tree trunks and other remains become cast fossils when their organic matter decays and is replaced with minerals. A fossilized bone no longer contains bone material; it has all been replaced! Depending on which minerals fill the mold, a cast fossil may look like dull cement or have spectacular sparkle. 
 A third type of fossil is the mold fossil. A mold fossil is an impression of the organism. We know about certain plants and animals simply because of impressions they left. 
 Finally, a trace fossil is other evidence that an organism existed. Fossilized nests, footprints, and animal dung are examples of trace fossils. 
 Fossils are constantly weathered or even destroyed by nature. For instance, fossils are lost when rocks undergo metamorphosis. Sometimes though, when erosion and other factors work together, fossils are revealed or become easier to access during geologic expeditions.

item.name: Grassland-P5.png
item.title: Fertile grasslands are used for agriculture

item.name: Grassland-P6.png
item.title: New Zealand farm on a grassland

item.name: Grassland-P8.png
item.title: Camouflaged giraffe in the African Bush

item.text: The word “fossil” comes from the Latin word fossilis, which means "dug up."
Paleontology is the study of life from former geologic periods. Paleontologists primarily study fossils.
The fossil record is sparse until about 600 million years ago.
The study of the fossilization process is called taphonomy.
When organisms fall to the sea floor, they can quickly become covered with sediment. Most fossils are excavated from sedimentary rock layers.
Ammonites are the most widely known fossil. Fossils suggest that spiral-shelled ammonites lived in the oceans until 65 million years ago.
A few places on Earth are especially known for preserving ancient life. They are called lagerstätten.
The oldest animal fossils come from the Burgess Shale in Canada and the Chengjiang Deposits in China.
Whole woolly mammoth fossils were found in 2012. Siberian scientists believe they could use DNA to revive this extinct species!
Whole fossils of leaves can preserve autumn colors from millions of years ago.
Fossils suggest that a gigantic shark lived between two million and 16 million years ago. The megalodon was 50 feet long.
The largest dinosaur fossil is of a sauroposeidon. Fossils suggest that sauroposeidons were 56 feet tall!
Carefully unearthing a large dinosaur fossil can take years. Tools used range from dental scrapers to sledgehammers.
According to the fossil record, the smallest avian dinosaur (or flying dinosaur) was about the size of a crow.
Paleontologists estimate the weight of ancient animals by measuring the depth of fossilized footprints.
Coprolites, or fossilized feces, can tell us what an animal ate.
Mold fossils can be filled with wax to make an impression that has the shape of the original life form.
By studying how rocks are layered, we can tell which rocks are the oldest. This helps us understand the fossils they hold.
Index fossils are those about which much is known. When an index fossil is found, it can provide clues about other fossils nearby.
Fossils are at least 10,000 years old. The oldest fossils found are approximately 3.5 billions years old.

Butterfly laying eggs in a garden
Grassland

item.question: What is needed to create a whole fossil?
When a tree trunk decays and its shape is replaced with minerals, it becomes a _______.
Woolly mammoth tracks are examples of ________.
Where are most fossils found?
What can we learn from fossils?

choice.answer: The shape of an animal's body

item.question: Why might fossils of the same species look different from each other?

choice.answer: They are made of different minerals.
Different amounts of oxygen were available during formation.

item.question: In general, which fossils give the best clues about animal behavior?
Since countless plants and animals have died, why isn't the Earth flooded with fossils?

choice.answer: Fossils are destroyed when rocks undergo metamorphic change.
Fossils are broken down by nature.
Not everything that dies becomes a fossil.

item.question: Why do many fossils come from the sea floor? Choose the best answer.

choice.answer: Land animals are washed out to sea.
Sea creatures are easily buried by sediment.
Most species live in the ocean.

item.question: Why are rock layers useful in the study of fossils?

choice.answer: They give clues about the organism's time period.
They are most likely to hold whole fossils.

item.question: What is most likely about a lagerstätten?

choice.answer: It is in a warm climate.
It has high low oxygen levels.

item.question: To make a mountain, what must occur?
What best explains the great number of ammonite fossil discoveries?

choice.answer: Ammonites' shells made cast fossilization possible.
Ammonites lived where many people live today.
Ammonites were preserved by tree sap or amber.

item.question: In the Grand Canyon, where are the oldest fossils most likely to be?

choice.answer: In the highest layers of rock
In the lowest layers of rock

item.question: The fossil record is sparse until about 600 million years ago. What explains this best?

choice.answer: Much more oxygen was present until 600 million years ago.
Lava has covered the older animal fossils.
Life became much more plentiful about 600 million years ago.
Sedimentary rock was not created until 600 million years ago.

hotspot.title: Amber
hotspot.text: Amber starts out as sticky tree sap that helps protect the plants from insects and to seal the plant wounds. As it hardens over time, insects and other organisms that get stuck in the resin, get fossilized.\n

hotspot.title: Fossil
hotspot.text: Fossilized tree resin or Amber can fossilize parts of an organism including small DNA fragments that are otherwise hard to preserve. The fossil resins can contain bacteria, fungi, insects, and plants.Some of the oldest ambers recovered are over 130 million years old.\n

hotspot.title: Fern
hotspot.text: This is a picture of a fossilized leaf of the fern Pecopteris arborescens from the Upper Carboniferous period over 300-360 million years ago.\n

hotspot.title: Coal
hotspot.text: This fossil is from the coal age or the Upper Carboniferous period. Bark bearing trees with lignin first appeared during this period. When plants died and decayed, they became buried and compressed by new organic material growing on top of them, forming thick layers of coal.\n

hotspotsOnBackground.backgroundText: Petrified wood or wood that has been turned to stone

hotspot.title: Petrified wood
hotspot.text: Petrified wood means wood turned into rock or stone. This picture shows a petrified wood sample where the organic materials in a tree have been replaced by minerals like quartz, while maintaining the original look and shape.\n

hotspot.title: Formation of petrified wood
hotspot.text: Petrified wood is unique because it is a three dimensional representation of a fossil. When wood is covered with sediment under the ground in an environment without oxygen, it cannot be decomposed. Water flowing through the sediments can slowly replace the organic materials with minerals. It may take over a 100 years to convert wood to petrified wood.\n

hotspot.title: Seeds of Katsura
hotspot.text: The Katsura is an ornamental tree found in Japan and China. It has heart shaped leaves with bright yellow, orange, or red colors. This is a fossil of the seeds of a Katsura tree found in Denmark and dates back to 55 million years ago during the marine geological formation call the Fur Formation.\n

hotspot.title: Fur formation
hotspot.text: The Fur formation in Denmark is a marine geological formation dating back to 55 million years ago. The formation has diatoms (type of algae) and clay covered with volcanic ash and limestone. This formation has lots of fossilized fish, insects, plants, and birds.\n

hotspot.title: Dinosaur footprints
hotspot.text: A trace fossil showing dinosaur footprints. Trace fossils are formed when an organism leaves impressions on an underlying substrate.\n

hotspot.title: Trace fossils
hotspot.text: Trace fossils are best preserved in sandstones. The can also form in shale and limestone. Unlike other fossils which are formed after the organism dies, trace fossils are created when the organism was alive.\n

hotspot.title: Dinosaur dig
hotspot.text: A fossil of a dinosaur showing well preserved teeth.\n

hotspot.title: Dinosaur
hotspot.text: Fossil of a dinosaur showing well preserved teeth.\n

hotspot.title: Paleontology
hotspot.text: A paleontologist studies studies fossils and prehistoric life to understand the environment and the evolution of organisms. Using a combination of science, mathematics, and engineering, a paleontologist works to understand the environment on Earth millions of years ago.\n

hotspot.title: Paleontologist tools
hotspot.text: A paleontologist needs a lot of tools to dig out the fossils without damaging them. Typical tools include chisels, shovels, picks, and brushes. First the fossil is prepared by removing the surrounding rock and debris after excavation. Next, the fossil is stabilized to ensure that it can be studied and displayed.\n

hotspot.title: Marine fossils
hotspot.text: Stromatolites are layered accretionary structures formed in shallow water by the trapping, binding and cementation of sedimentary grains by biofilms of microorganisms, especially cyanobacteria (commonly known as blue-green algae).Stromatolites provide some of the most ancient records of life on Earth by fossil remains which date back more than 3.5 billion years ago.\n

hotspot.title: Marine fossils
hotspot.text: Stromatolites are layered accretionary structures formed in shallow water by the trapping, binding and cementation of sedimentary grains by biofilms of microorganisms, especially cyanobacteria (commonly known as blue-green algae).Stromatolites provide some of the most ancient records of life on Earth by fossil remains which date back more than 3.5 billion years ago.\n
